awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Impact of microbial and termite communities on transfer of decaying wood to stable and protected mineral soil carbon pools
awd_abstract_narration:
As forests age, the death of trees adds dead wood to the forest floor.  Even in younger forests, strong wind events, insect outbreaks, fire and forest management all can result in accumulation of dead wood.  Dead wood stores carbon, but how much in the long-term is uncertain.  Much of the carbon in wood is slowly returned to the atmosphere as CO2 during decomposition. Some, however, also enters the soil, where it can be stored for decades to centuries.  In 2011, pine, aspen and birch logs were placed in nine forests across the U.S. to help determine how factors such as climate, wood type, presence of termites and fungi affect wood decomposition rate.  The wood used had a unique carbon isotopic signature that allows the research team to trace it as it enters the soil, and to measure how fast carbon is either lost to decomposition or stored as soil carbon. This knowledge will improve understanding of carbon cycling in forests and allow better prediction of how a changing climate or increased tree death from forest disturbance could alter carbon storage in forests. This research will help to determine if forests will be carbon sinks or sources for atmospheric CO2 over long time scales. The project will also give middle and high school students a chance to experience scientific research first-hand, and increase awareness of STEM topics in rural schools near four of the research sites. Project scientists will work with teachers to involve students in research-based discovery and analysis at a nearby field site and incorporate project topics related to ecology and soil science in school curricula, providing a foundation for increasing student interest in science and engineering careers.

The fungal and invertebrate communities that dominate wood decomposition have distinct lignin and carbohydrate decomposition pathways along a white- to brown-rot continuum, and these alter the amount of carbon diverted to the mineral soil.  This study's specific objectives are to assess the role of different fungal/bacterial communities and termites on lignin- and carbohydrate-decay pathways for the three wood types and determine how this affects wood carbon movement into labile and protected mineral soil carbon pools. This entails: 1) using the 13C signature of labelled wood to assess the role of decomposer community function on wood-decay pathways, mass loss, and wood carbon movement into mineral soil; and 2) using a unique series of termite-exclusion plots to determine the effect of termite activity on fungal wood-decay community composition, wood-decay pathways, and incorporation of wood carbon into the mineral soil.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This report is from research covered in a portion of the award to the University of Minnesota. The PI for the larger effort is faculty at Michigan Tech University, and collaborators include scientists from across the United States, including scientists at the U.S. Forest Service. Broader Impacts were largely addressed in other award lines for this project, and this Report covers research addressing Scientific Merit specific to microbial community assembly and carbon fates in wood, as a function of wood species and ground contact.

The project aims, overall, were to match the fate of 13C-labeled wood to its decomposer fungal assembly as decaying wood became incorporated sub-soil or was lost to the atmosphere as a result of decomposition. There were 9 sites used for this work, throughout the United States, among which large logs from previous FACE research sites have been deployed either on the ground or in vertical position. Sampling of the logs for microbial community DNA was done pre-pandemic, including an effort to archive samples that made them available without site visits. Re-sampling, however, particularly for soil 13C work, was delayed by the pandemic, leaving a connection between microbes and their consequences for future analyses made possible by project extension.

For the larger experiment, loblolly pine (Pinus taeda L.), aspen (Populus tremuloides Michx.), and paper birch (Betula papyrifera Marshall) logs were incubated in the field in forests with varying soil and environmental conditionsl Logs were sourced from Free Air Carbon Dioxide Enrichment (FACE) sites in North Carolina and Wisconsin. The wood has distinct δ13C signatures that enable tracking during decay. In 2011, logs were placed horizontally in ground contact or vertically without soil contact. Samples have been taken a various moments along the decay continuum, through to the present (2022).

The Schilling Lab at the University of Minnesota was specifically interested in the incorporation dynamics of carbon as a function of the selectivity of carbohydrates relative to wood lignin. Thus, the group, working closely with the Forest Products Laboratory PI (Lindner), has been focused on matching decomposer communities to their rot type outcomes - highly carbohydrate-selective "brown rot-type" fungi may shunt more lignin-derived 13C to the soil, relative to "white rot-type" fungi that use a requisite lignin removal step and remove more carbon, overall. This was enabled using DNA extractions taken from sampling efforts pre-pandemic, along with archived decayed wood (within a 6-year window) that could provide physiochemical information about decay type dominance.

In this work, we have shown a predominance of white rot-type fungi and white rot-processes in this FACE wood. Some brown rot was apparent and related both to wood species (more brown rot in pine) and to log 'presentation' in ground contact versus aboveground (no ground contact). This result was reflected in lower lignin loss (relative to density loss - L/D) in samples trending as brown rot (below a well-known 0.8 L/D threshold). Amplicon sequencing of the fungal communities using ITS-2 primers, however, revealed higher numbers of soft rot fungi than brown rot fungi in those samples deemed 'brown rot' using the L/D. Soft rot is another carbohydrate-selective decay type that is often not addressed in decay studies.

Collectively, these results show the immense white rot influence on wood decay in the temperate U.S., and suggest soft rot processes should be assessed alongside brown rot, instead of using traditional binary rot type approaches. Some analyses must, however, wait for 13C data. The overall study is very large, geographically-distributed across the entire U.S., and challenging for the larger collaborative to resample during the COVID pandemic. The completed project and data from this dedicated effort in Minnesota (and collaborative with other PIs), to correlate fungal communities with rot type outcomes, will serve as foundational data for a future correlation with 13C data from collaborators (grant still active, in extension). We still need to link these data for microbial community assembly to carbon storage, using the L/D rot type as a linker.

This research generated a stand-alone publication in Fungal Ecology (online first; doi.org/10.1016/j.funeco.2022.101151) that is also supported by a US Forest Service, General Technical Report SRS–262 that outlines the project steps, as context. Two postdoctoral scholars (Maillard; Jusino), and two students-turned-technicians (Moran; Andrews) were trained in this effort. The work sets the stage for future work, and given the amplitude of sampling effort, represents a major repeated-measures study to influence and inform future work.
